text:
Hi. I would like to integrate the chat function on our website. The Website isn't hosted on HubSpot but on our server and is using Typo3.
First question: is it possible to integrate this chat function on an external site ?
Second question:  how does the connection work? through the tracking code from HubSpot?
hey <@UFBA31SP5>, yes you can do that with just adding tracking code on site
thanks for the answer. And do you know if it's possible to integrate the call function in the chat window? A bit like the chat box HubSpot is using
yes you can add the steps and can ask for the number or email
Does it work only for Sales or also for Marketing Hub?

If I'm using the tracking code from HubSpot on my website, should I use the cookie bar from HubSpot? We already have a cookie bar to inform people that we are using cookies.
Is there anything specific related to GPDR that I should look after?

If you already have a sufficient cookie bar you don’t need to use the HubSpot one instead. GDPR wise there is a toggle in content settings for enabling GDPR features. Whether you need to enable those features or not you should ask a lawyer, or bring it up to the business you are building the site for and ask them to consult a lawyer to see if they need to comply.

Seeing as HubSpot makes it relatively easy to comply with most aspects of GDPR and seeing as GDPR’s rules are basically best practice anyways, many people opt to just skip the lawyer and do it anyways, whether or not they are legally required to.

Sweet, I can finally send people all my Milli Vanilli albums!
lol

There used to be a similar tool that unfortunately eventually got taken down(another service bought them out then they went under). It was a bit unique, it was called pipebytes.

It was a website similar to this where you upload a file then send someone a link or a code to enter. And the interesting part was the way they handled uploading/downloading.

The file would upload to the server at first until the recipient started downloading, then once the recipient started downloading it would create  some sort of direct SSL transmission between your computer and the recipients computer to transmit the rest of the file. The pipebytes server itself, would instantly delete the file after 100% completion of the download on the user’s end. Both the sender and recipient could see the upload/download progress.

So if you had the recipient already on the page before the sender started the upload, the connection supposedly was completely direct, no file stored on pipebytes.

It was pretty freaking cool.
That is pretty cool... like a torrent client almost
late on this but my bf is 100% on board with you for this...let me know if you find any good extensions I can share with him

We use it internally at HubSpot for all JS code
It is what I use

hello, just another q, is there a time limit on the track practical exam? there's a timer in it and tbh i haven't click yet bc i get priority tasks over HubSpot. is it okay for me to give at least an hour of my work time per day to do it, or it's a full on no excuse type of exam? bc i at least would like to get a head start on it while i have down time at work. thanks!

I don't think there's like a ticking clock counting down on the practicum. Even if there was you could retake it later and submit the same 1.

The multiple choice test, that one does have a timer i believe. I think the estimated time he said it could take is like 45 mins. I think i finished in about 15 minutes, and that was while also taking screenshots to provide feedback. Take your time on it though to prevent accidentally tripping yourself up. And even if youve been doing HubSpot dev work a long time review the cms for developers course before taking it as some questions are based on the course and you may not know the answer just from experience.
